description: Foundational tax and business law concepts to build confidence before diving into harder REG topics

questions.question: Under IRC Section 61, gross income includes:

options.B: All income from whatever source derived, unless specifically excluded
options.C: Only income reported on Form W-2

questions.explanation: IRC Section 61 defines gross income broadly as 'all income from whatever source derived' unless a specific exclusion applies. This includes wages, interest, dividends, business income, gains, and more.
questions.tip: IRC 61 = ALL income is taxable unless Congress says otherwise. Start broad, then look for exclusions.

questions.question: Which filing status generally provides the most favorable tax rates for a taxpayer with dependents?
questions.explanation: Qualifying Surviving Spouse (formerly Qualifying Widow(er)) uses the same favorable rates as Married Filing Jointly for two years after spouse's death. Head of Household is next most favorable, then Single, with MFS typically least favorable.
questions.tip: Rate favorability: MFJ/QSS > HOH > Single > MFS. MFS usually worst due to phase-outs.

questions.question: A taxpayer should itemize deductions when:

options.B: Their itemized deductions exceed the standard deduction

questions.explanation: Taxpayers should choose the larger of their standard deduction or itemized deductions. Itemizing only makes sense when total itemized deductions (mortgage interest, state taxes, charity, etc.) exceed the standard deduction.
questions.tip: Itemize vs. Standard = whichever is LARGER. For 2024: $14,600 single, $29,200 MFJ.

questions.conceptTested: Above vs below the line deductions
questions.question: Deductions 'for AGI' (above the line) are more valuable than 'from AGI' deductions because:

options.B: They reduce AGI, which can increase eligibility for other tax benefits
options.C: They are only available to high-income taxpayers
options.D: They can be claimed without receipts

questions.explanation: Above-the-line deductions reduce AGI directly, which can: (1) increase eligibility for credits/deductions that phase out at higher AGI, (2) reduce taxes in states using federal AGI, and (3) are available even if you don't itemize.
questions.tip: Above the line = reduces AGI = more valuable. Below the line = only helps if you itemize.

questions.question: Long-term capital gains (assets held more than one year) are generally taxed at rates that are:

options.B: The same as ordinary income rates

questions.explanation: Long-term capital gains are taxed at preferential rates of 0%, 15%, or 20% depending on income level—lower than ordinary income rates which go up to 37%. This encourages long-term investment.
questions.tip: LTCG rates: 0%/15%/20%. Much better than ordinary rates (up to 37%). Hold > 1 year!

questions.question: A $1,000 tax credit is more valuable than a $1,000 tax deduction because:

options.A: Credits can be carried forward indefinitely
options.B: A credit reduces tax liability dollar-for-dollar, while a deduction only reduces taxable income
options.C: Credits are not subject to phase-outs
options.D: Deductions are limited to 50% of AGI

questions.explanation: A $1,000 credit reduces your tax bill by $1,000 directly. A $1,000 deduction only reduces taxable income by $1,000, saving taxes based on your marginal rate (e.g., 22% bracket = $220 saved).
questions.tip: Credit = dollar-for-dollar reduction in TAX. Deduction = reduces taxable INCOME. Credit > Deduction.

questions.question: Which element is NOT required for a valid contract?
questions.explanation: Valid contracts require: (1) offer and acceptance, (2) consideration (exchange of value), (3) legal capacity (competent parties), and (4) legal purpose. Most contracts do NOT require writing—oral contracts are generally valid, except where the Statute of Frauds applies.
questions.tip: Contract elements: Offer, Acceptance, Consideration, Capacity, Legality. Writing usually NOT required.

questions.question: Which business entity provides limited liability to ALL its owners while allowing pass-through taxation by default?
questions.explanation: An LLC provides limited liability to all members (like a corporation) while being taxed as a pass-through entity by default (like a partnership). General partnerships and sole proprietorships don't provide limited liability. C corps have double taxation.
questions.tip: LLC = best of both worlds: limited liability + pass-through taxation (default).

questions.question: Circular 230 governs:

options.B: Practice before the IRS by tax practitioners

questions.explanation: Treasury Department Circular 230 establishes rules for practitioners (CPAs, attorneys, enrolled agents) who practice before the IRS. It covers due diligence, conflicts of interest, fees, advertising, and penalties for violations.
questions.tip: Circular 230 = Treasury rules for IRS practice. Covers CPAs, attorneys, EAs before IRS.

questions.question: A taxpayer's 'basis' in property generally represents:

options.A: The property's current fair market value
options.B: The taxpayer's investment in the property for tax purposes
options.C: The amount the property is insured for
options.D: The property's assessed value for local taxes

questions.explanation: Basis represents the taxpayer's investment in property for tax purposes. It's used to determine gain or loss on sale (Amount realized - Basis = Gain/Loss) and depreciation deductions. Initial basis is usually cost.
questions.tip: Basis = your investment for tax purposes. Gain/Loss = Sales Price - Basis.

questions.question: Which of the following would disqualify a corporation from S corporation status?

options.B: Having a shareholder who is a nonresident alien
options.C: Having only one class of stock

questions.explanation: S corporations cannot have nonresident alien shareholders. Other requirements: max 100 shareholders (family members count as one), only individuals/estates/certain trusts as shareholders, one class of stock, domestic corporation.
questions.tip: S corp killers: >100 shareholders, nonresident aliens, corps as shareholders, multiple stock classes.

questions.question: Under the Statute of Frauds, which contract must be in writing to be enforceable?

options.A: A contract to paint a house for $400
options.B: A contract to sell a car for $600
options.C: A contract to sell real property

questions.explanation: The Statute of Frauds requires writing for: (1) contracts for sale of land, (2) contracts that cannot be performed within one year, (3) promises to pay another's debt, (4) marriage contracts, and (5) sale of goods $500+ (UCC).
questions.tip: Statute of Frauds (MY LEGS): Marriage, Year+, Land, Executor, Goods $500+, Surety.

questions.question: Under MACRS, which convention applies to most personal property placed in service during the year?
questions.explanation: The half-year convention treats all personal property as placed in service at the midpoint of the year, allowing half a year's depreciation in the first and last years. Real property uses the mid-month convention.
questions.tip: Personal property = half-year convention. Real property = mid-month convention.

questions.question: A partnership is considered a:

options.A: Taxable entity that pays income tax on its earnings
options.B: Pass-through entity that reports income but partners pay the tax

questions.explanation: Partnerships are pass-through entities. The partnership files Form 1065 and issues Schedule K-1s to partners, but doesn't pay entity-level tax. Partners report their share of income on personal returns and pay tax individually.
questions.tip: Partnership = pass-through. No entity tax. Partners pay on their share via K-1.

questions.question: Section 1231 property includes:

options.C: Depreciable business property held more than one year

questions.explanation: Section 1231 property includes depreciable business property and real property used in a trade or business, held more than one year. Net 1231 gains are taxed as LTCG; net 1231 losses are ordinary losses—the 'best of both worlds.'
questions.tip: Section 1231 = business property held >1 year. Gains = LTCG rates. Losses = ordinary. Win-win!
